titlestmt.author: Michelle Runyon

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina

did.abstract: The Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina operated in the late 1970s and early 1980s to advocate for the human rights of Argentines targeted during the Dirty War/El Proceso. The committee was formed by prominent Argentines who had resettled in the United States, especially in the Washington, D.C. area. The committee frequently partnered with other human rights organizations, including the Washington Office on Latin America, to sponsor programming and mailings to raise awareness of the situation in Argentina. The Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina records consist of correspondence, mailers, flyers, reports, notes, programming information, petitions, lists, pamphlets, newspaper clippings, poetry, photographs, posters, and journal articles.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina (WCHRA) was founded in 1977 following Argentine dictator Jorge Rafael Videla's rise to power and the beginning of the Proceso de Reorganización Nacional/National Reorganization Process. The committee raised awareness of human rights abuses in Argentina, circulated petitions, and collected testimonies of victims. They also dialogued with government officials as well as professional organizations to change their stances and policies on Argentina in light of human rights abuses perpetrated there. The committee consisted of Argentines living in the United States, mainly in Washington, D.C. The membership consisted primarily of educated professionals and academics including Tomas Gergely, Ana Lajmanovich, and Juan E. Méndez.

The committee often partnered with larger human rights organizations, including the Washington Office on Latin America and the Association Solidarite Franco Argentine (A.S.F.A). WCHRA largely became inactive by the mid-1980s.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2019.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Washington Committee for Human Rights in Argentina records document its members' advocacy for the rights of Argentines and their efforts to document human rights abuses during the Dirty War/El Proceso. The collection comprises three series: the Administrative Files series, 1964-1984; the Publications series, 1965-1986; and the Subject Files series, 1973-2016. The Administrative Files series consists of the materials that directly document the work of committee members to do outreach and lobby government officials to support changes in U.S. foreign policy towards Argentina. The Publications series consists of full-length publications. The Subjects Files series consists of newspaper clippings, photographs, flyers from other organizations, posters, and wires. Materials are primarily in English and Spanish with some materials in French, Italian, and Portuguese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of working documents of WCHRA including information about events, internal memos, external correspondence, reports, programs, testimonies of victims, and documents from other organizations. The testimonies of victims were largely gathered by WCHRA members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folders consist of different versions of the petition regarding disappeared scientists distributed by the WCHRA, notes, and lists of names for the petition. Notable signatories include George Wald, Salvador Luria, and Noam Chomsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Publications series consists of publications gathered by WCHRA members. The contents largely cover El Proceso/the Dirty War, the disappeared, human rights abuses, American foreign policy towards Argentina, scientists' responses to human rights abuses and Argentine Jews targeted during El Proceso/the Dirty War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The reports largely detail human rights in Latin America, the treatment of Argentine Jews during the Dirty War, or human rights advocacy work by professional scientific organizations.

did.unittitle: Science and Human Rights Uruguay and the Southern Cone
Scientists and Human Rights in Latin America
Separata Movimiento Ecuménico por los Derechos Humanos (MEDH)
The Argentine Situation Concerning Human Rights

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject Files series consists of newspaper clippings, flyers, posters, newsletters, drawings, photographs, poetry, magazine articles, and wires. Some of these materials were annotated by WCHRA members and appear to have been circulated among members.

Somos familiares padres or tíos de niños desaparecidos en Argentina

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This pamphlet outlines stories of the disappearanced relatives of Osiris Dominguez, Mabel Castro de Dominguez, Marta Enseñat, Nelson Hernandez, Adolfo Luis Lopez Mateos, Jorge Nadal, Julio Ramirez, and Adalberto Eraldo Rossetti. It includes lists of facts about the disappeared, newspaper clippings about their cases, and personal statements from the relatives who created the pamphlet.
